Name: su xin hua
jasmine flower
Botanical: Jasminum grandiflorum (Synonym:Jasminum grandiflorum; Jasminum officinale var. grandiflorum; Jasminum officinale var. affine; Jasminum affine)

Maladies Treated: Sexual impotence due to gan qi yu jie
Discomfort of the chest of rib cage
Dosage: Oral administration: decoction or tea. Buds: 6–9 g [2]. Whole herb: 15–30 g [3].
Samples of Formulae:
Name of Formula: Gan Mai Da Zao Tang (Licorice, Wheat and Jujube Decoction) with added ingredients [5]
Application: Crying for no reason, difficulty in emotional self-control, anxiety, depression.
Composition: Zhi Gan Cao (honey-fried licorice root) 15 g, Da Zao (jujube) 30 g, Fu Xiao Mai (light wheat) 30 g, Mei Gui Hua (rose flower) 4.5 g, Mo Li Hua (jasmine flower) 4.5 g, Su Xin Hua (jasmine flower) 3 g, Ren Shen Hua (ginseng flower) 3 g, Sheng Shi Jue Ming (raw abalone shell) 45 g, Sheng Mu Li (raw oyster shell) 45 g. Water decoction for oral use.
Research: Antiviral efficacy against hepatitis B virus replication of oleuropein isolated from su xin hua (Jasminum spp.) was reported. [4]
Notes: Oleuropein is also called: olive bitter glycoside (橄欖苦甙), olive bitter principle (橄欖苦素), olive bitter glucoside (橄欖苦苷), olive leaf extract (油橄欖葉提取物), western olive bitter glycoside (洋橄欖苦甙).
Chemical Ingredients: Jasminum grandiflorum (blooming flowers): linalool (芳樟醇), benzyl acetate (乙酸苯甲酯), (Z)-3-hexenyl benzoate (苯甲酸(Z)-3-乙烯酯), indole (吲哚), jasmine lacetone (素馨內酯), methyl jasmonate (茉莉酮酸甲酯).
Jasminum officinale (buds): phytol (植物醇), linalool (芳樟醇).

Jasminum officinale (blooming flowers): p-allylphenol (對-烯丙基苯酚), benzyl acetate (乙酸苄酯), cis-jasmone (順式-茉莉酮), nerol (橙花醇), geraniol (牻牛兒醇), indole (吲哚), methyl (4-iso-propanyl) benzoate (4-異丙基苯甲酸甲酯), hexyl benzoate (苯甲酸己烯酯), trimethylpentadecanone (三甲基十五碳酮), isophytol (異植醇), cinnamyl benzoate (苯甲酸桂皮酯), isophytyl acetate (乙酸異植醇酯), geranylgeraniol (牻牛兒醇基牻牛兒醇), phytyl acetate (乙酸植醇酯), geranylgeraniol acetate (乙酸牻牛兒醇基牻牛兒醇基牻牛兒醇酯).

Name: chuan dong zhang ya cai
Other name: qing yu dan cao 青魚膽草

Geography: All over the world; about 170 varieties.
Mainly distributed in Asia, Africa, North America.
China: about 79 varieties; mainly distributed in western part of Hunan, Yunnan, Sichuan, Guizhou, Zongqing, Qinghai, and western part of Hubei; especially in the south western part of China.
Maladies Treated: Red and swollen eyes (acute conjunctivitis) 目赤腫痛 (急性结膜炎).
Since the 70's it is being used as folk's medicine for hepatitis B, cancer of the liver, cirrhosis of the liver with good result.
Medical Function: Clears heat and toxin (清熱解毒).
Dosage: Take orally: make decoction 3 to 9 g, or make into powder form and mix into boiling water. External application: appropriate amount, smash and apply to affected area.
Research:
Antibiotic: Chuan dong zhang ya cai extract can inhibit Gram-positive bacteria. Its effective concentrate can be diluted to as high as 1:128. The decoction of the whole herb can also inhibit various bacteria, like: Staphylococcus albus, Non-coagulate Vibrio, typhoid bacteria, paratyphoid type A bacteria, Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella boydii, Shigella flexneri.

Anti-inflammatory: Gentian alkaloid possesses the effect of anti-inflammatory, anti-allergenic, enhancing the effect of sedatives and enhance the effect of analgesics.

Liver protection: Its ursolic acid can obviously lower the liver enzyme ALT of laboratory white rats, induced by CCl4. Methylswertianin possesses anti-tuberculosis effect, enhances the function of the liver, and improves the liver enzyme system. Iridoid glycoside can lower Alanine transaminase (ALT), improve liver function, and protect the cells of the liver.

Cardiovascular protection: Xanthones and other ingredients possess strong anti-oxidation effect, inhibing the oxidation of lipids. In studies, it shows that the anti OFR (oxygen free radical) activity is 7 times stronger than vitamin E. The studies showed that those chemical ingredients can inhibit the damage of lab rats' angeial endothelium by inhibiting LDL, and lower the density of asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA) and possess anti atherosclerosis. One of the main ingredients, demethylbellidifolin, protects the myocardium against damage due to ischemia-reperfusion in rats. [4]

Hair growth promotion effect: The ingredient swertiamarin possesses hair growth promotion effect.
Notes: This herb is mainly being used in Sichuan, Hubei, and Hunan areas. The name chuan dong means eastern part of Sichuan province where it was originated.
Chemical Ingredients: swertianolin (獐牙菜口山酮甙; 當藥甙)

bellidifolin (1,5,8-Trihydroxy-3-methoxy-9H-xanthen-9-one; 1,5,8-Trihydroxy-3-methoxyxanthone; Bellidifoline; 3-Methoxy-1,5,8-trihydroxyxanthen-9-one; 9H-Xanthen-9-one, 1,5,8-trihydroxy-3-methoxy- (9ci); Bellidifolium; Brn 0288441) (雛菊葉龍膽酮)
desmethylbellidifolin / demethylbellidifolin (去甲基雛菊葉龍膽酮)
ursolic acid (熊果酸; 烏蘇酸)
daviditin A (川東獐牙菜素 A)
daviditin B (川東獐牙菜素 B)

Name: HE SHOU WU
SHOU WU
Ye jiao teng
Botanical: Cynanchum Welfordii Hemsl. (the variety found in Korea)
Common: fo-ti (a made-up name in Hawaii, for commercial purposes)

Geography: Polygonum multiflorum Thunb.: Henan; Hubei; Guangxi; Guangdong; Guizhou; Sichuan.
Properties: Zhi shou wu (prepared): sweet, astringent, slightly warm.
Sheng shou wu (raw): sweet, bitter, neutral.
Meridians: Sheng shou wu (raw): Heart; Liver; Large Intestine.
Maladies Treated: Yin deficiency or blood deficiency with hyperlipemia.
Heat toxicity (re du): eczema, sores, carbuncles, goiter, scrofula, inflammation of lymph nodes.
Secure essence (jing): spermatorrhea, vaginal discharge, vulvovaginitis.
Qi deficiency (qixu) and blood deficiency with chronic malaria.
Boils: leaves (ye jiao teng) used externally to expel pus.
Medical Function:: Improving the development of red blood cells.
Ye jiao teng decoction has a calming effect.
Samples of Formulae:
For split personality: He Shou Wu (fleece flower root) 90 g, Ye Jiao Teng (Polygonum multiflorum vine) 90 g, Hong Zao (red jujube) 2–6 pieces. Boil with water and use as tea.

For premature white hair: Zhi He Shou Wu (prepared fleece flower root) 30 g, Shu Di Huang (prepared Rehmannia root) 30 g, Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis) 15 g. Soak in 1000 c.c. of rice wine for 10–15 days. Use 15–30 c.c. per day.

For nerve injuries: He Shou Wu (fleece flower root) 30 g. Boil in water. Take in the morning and at night for one month (one course of treatment).

For malaria: He Shou Wu (fleece flower root) 12 g, Gan Cao (licorice) 12 g. Make into a decoction.

For blood deficiency: Ren Shen Yang Rong Tang (Ginseng Nourishing Decoction).

For boils to expel pus: use Ye Jiao Teng (Polygonum multiflorum vine) leaves externally.
Contraindications:
Use caution in cases of spleen deficiency (pixu). Not to use in presence of phlegm or diarrhea due to shenyangxu. There are reports that this herb has caused liver inflammation in some patients.

Beware: "Ben he shou wu" sold along roadsides in Taiwan is huang yao zi, not he shou wu, and is toxic. It cannot be taken frequently. In Taiwan some locally grown products add the prefix "ben" and some refer to huang yao zi as ben shou wu.

Toxicity of huang yao zi (not he shou wu): The roots of huang yao and ling yu zi (the pearly sprouts under the leaves) contain toxin. Over-consumption can cause burning sensation of the mouth and tongue, drooling, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constricted pupils; if serious, cardiac paralysis, difficulty in breathing, coma and death.

Antidote (English text): empty the stomach, promote diarrhea, take egg white, or ge gen starch porridge, and activated carbon; drink cane sugar solution, or intravenous feeding of glucose solution. Taking mung bean soup or boil gang mei gen 250 grams with 5 bowls of water and simmer till 2 bowls and use as tea.

Antidote (Chinese text): 洗胃，導瀉，內服蛋清或葛粉糊及活性炭；飲糖水或靜脈滴注葡萄糖鹽水，亦有用綠豆湯內服；或用岡梅根50克，用清水5碗煎至2碗飲服。
Research:
He shou wu powder can lower the blood cholesterol, triglyceride, b-lipoprotein (LDL) of high lipid animals. They were lowered by 89%, 42%, and 54% respectively. The triglyceride of the liver was lowered by 52%.

The ingredient of he shou wu, 2,3,5,4'-tetrahydroxystibene-2O-b-D-glucoside possesses a strong inhibiting effect on fatty liver formation, and liver damage of rats caused by oxidized corn oil. It also inhibits the elevation of serum ALT, AST and lipid peroxydation (LPO), and the damaging of the liver.

He shou wu can lower serum free fatty acid and lipid peroxydation.

In vitro studies showed that he shou wu can protect liver, anti-fatty liver formation because it can inhibit lipid oxidation and the destruction of liver cells.

He shou wu is being used improve the function of the liver, in fatty liver, and in viral hepatitis.

Among the the 4 different kinds of prepared he shou wu, raw he shou wu possesses the strongest property in eliminating free radicals. The strength of the different preparations in eliminating free radicals is in the the following order: raw he shou wu, soy bean prepared he shou wu, steamed he shou wu, and soy plus alcohol prepared he shou wu. 中國人民解放軍總醫院藥劑科藥師等人利用1，1-二苯基-2-三硝基苯肼法（DPPH法）對4種何首烏炮制品清除自由基的能力進行了研究。結果表明，4種何首烏炮制品的抑制率由高到低排序為：生品>豆制品>清蒸品>豆加酒制品，生何首烏清除自由基的能力最強。(來源: 中國醫藥報, 2005年3月1日)
Notes:
He shou wu is the root of Polygonum multiflorum Thunb. It is harvested during fall and winter after the leaves become wilted.

The plant is called Ye Jiao Teng (literally “vines that tangle at night”).

“Fo-ti” is a commercial name made up by a Hawaiian merchant; it is not a traditional name.
Chemical Ingredients: tetrahydroxystilbene glucoside (四羥基二苯乙烯甙)
